It wasn't that long ago I was at the top of it! It used to be more open to the public, you used to be able to get the key from Rose Cottage across the road. But that cottage went sometime ago to be replaced by shops, and now you have to organise a trip to the top with the OPW.

It was an absolute pleasure to meet you too Carol, and no I managed to avoid the rest of the day's showers!

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
There is an absolutely gorgeous story in Alfred Webb's "Recollections of a Three Day's Ramble in County Wicklow" (NLI: P 358(2)) where he writes of his visit in 1850 about meeting two beggar girls as he walked out of the monastery towards the inn at Glendalough:
On our way back to the inn our progress was stopped by a pair of beggar girls who had fastened some bramble twigs, tied together with rags, across a narrow part of the road, and declared we were not to pass until we had paid toll; which we accordingly did. A little farther on a girl accosted us, wanting to know if “yer honers ud buy the top of St. Kivin’s tumbrella,” (umbrella) but we politely declined the offer.
It gets me every time!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39393844@N04] Gorgeous, Michael! Tumbrella is a great word - think I'll borrow it, if you don't mind. I'm sure Alfred Webb wouldn't begrudge it...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
Might as well throw in some dear old George Petrie. His assessment of the oratory in 1845 was:
That this building, in its original state, was at once the habitation and oratory of the eminent ecclesiastic to whom the religious establishment of Glendalough owed its origin, I see no reason to doubt; and it is highly probable that it received, shortly after his death, those additions which were necessary to make it a church, fit for the worship of those who would be led thither from reverence to his name; and in this opinion I am strengthened by a very valuable record in the Annals of the Four Masters, which proves, that this building was known by the appellation of Cro Caoimhghin, or St. Kevin’s House, in the middle of the twelfth century. The passage is as follows: ‘A. D. 1163. Glendalough was burned with Cro Cairain, Cro Caoimhghin, and the church of the two Sinchells’”
Petrie also drew about a million sketches of the antiquities at Glendalough!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/photoken04]  I was shooting colour slide film in 1960.
I started with 120 Agfa roll film in an Ilford Sporti camera shooting 12 exposures 6x6cm.
The film came back from the processor in an envelope as 4 strips of 3 exposures.
I then mounted 6x6 centimetre slides in big square plastic frames.

By 1962 I was using 35mm film producing 24x36mm slides.
The film came back from Kodak or Ilford ready mounted in 5x5cm cardboard mounts.
Sometimes I peeled open the card mount to put the slide into a plastic frame mount.
The advantage of using plastic frames with Newlo glass is that the heat of the projector lamp did not make the slide "pop" and go out-of-focus.
All old-tech now.
The NLI could open up one of  Richard Tilbrook's mounts to see what make of film he used. It was always marked beside the sprockets.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Thanks, real colour photos, not those creepy painted glass negatives from the early years... :)

comment.author: 64848937@N00
comment._content: A nice sylviculture record of the hill behind the Kitchen.  The blue green trees are Sitka Spruce planted by the Irish Forestry Board - indeed they look fairly young - maybe from the 50s?  Indeed many visitors to the Valley tend to think of it as ancient woodland but the mining at the Upper Lake resulted in the complete deforestation of the site by the 19th century.  It's time Crann removed the conifers and replaced them with native sessile oak and some locally sourced Scot's pine.  Sitka needles attract negative ions from the atmosphere and with water run off this results in acid.  The acid leaks down onto the woodland floor and together with the fallen needles results in an acid soil causing leaching and acid water run off into the lakes.

comment.author: 77181682@N02
comment._content:
Hi 
coming back very late to make a comment on this picture.
The girl is Moira Doyle, or at least she was then. She is now and has been since 1964 Moira Laffan In other words Mrs. nintytwo.
In the early sixties people of that age began to go hill walking in Wicklow and other mountains in Ireland.
Wearing trousers was by women was considered very odd and often attracted remarks as wer walked across O'Connell Bridge having returned on the Enniskerry bus from the hills.
This group started walking with the Irish German Society and with the Irish Austrian Society groups promoted by their embassies. I think the embassies frowned on those who joined their cultural groups only to go hillwalking and so the walkers started their own walking group The Ramblers, Now a very large national walking group celebrating 50 years very soon.
When this bunch began to get married and have small children whom they wanted to bring out to the graet outdoors  the hardy hikers got a bit fed up with them, so an offshoot (the split as usual in Ireland ) group was formed called Na Coisithe Family outdoor group. All the kids are grown up and we still walk the hills, but not so far or so fast now. So there you have it, that picture marks the beginning of  hiking groups in Ireland. A lot of water has gone under that bridge since then.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nintytwo] And I, in turn, am coming back very late to your excellent comment! Just to confirm Moira Doyle / Moira Laffan / Mrs nintytwo is in the blue trousers and red jumper?? Please send our best wishes to Mrs nintytwo...

Fascinating history of walking groups, and you made me laugh about the splinter groups.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
